Departament de Química Inorgànica i Orgànica, secció de Química Inorgànica & Institut de Nanociència i Nanotecnología (IN2UB), Universitat de Barcelona Martí i Franquès 1-11 Barcelona 08028 Spain 1 Present address: Sustainable Materials, Flemish Institute for Technological Research (VITO NV), Boeretang 200, 2400 Mol, Belgium. We show the applicability of a preparation method, previously reported for obtaining tailored bulk VCx catalysts, for alumina-supported G5TMCs. The characteristics of the G5TMCs/Al2O3 catalysts and their behaviour in the selective reduction of CO2 to CO through the RWGS reaction is reported. VCx/Al2O3 catalysts were active, stable and highly selective; meanwhile NbC/Al2O3 and TaC/Al2O3 were not active. VCx/Al2O3 catalysts exhibited selectivity to CO over 99.5 % at temperature above 773 K. The characteristics of alumina-supported vanadium carbide particles depended on the vanadium precursor and on the atmosphere used during the catalyst preparation. XPS characterization of VCx/Al2O3 catalysts revealed the presence of carbide species on surface before and after RWGS reaction. The catalytic behaviour of VCx/Al2O3 is analysed in the light of their characteristics and compared with bulk VCx counterparts. The most performant catalyst, VC(Pr)/Al2O3 , was stable over 4 days at 723 K, with ∼100 % selectivity to CO and CO2 conversion of ∼11 %. Graphical Abstract Keywords CO2 utilization Syngas RWGS VCx/Al2O3 NbC/Al2O3 TaC/Al2O3 Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Nowadays, the use of CO2 as C1 feedstock for chemicals and fuels production is a main target for contributing to the reduction of atmospheric CO2 concentration. Moreover, the green hydrogen production is called to highly increase in a short time, and this opens new opportunities for the CO2 utilization from the environmental point of view. The Reverse Water Gas Shift (RWGS) reaction (Eq. 1) can be considered a key point for the use CO2 as a cheap and abundant C1 feedstock in CO production, which can be used after H2O separation in the chemical industry and synthetic fuel production. (1) C O 2 + H 2 ↔ CO + H 2 O Δ H 298 0 = 42.1 kJ mol − 1 Many studies on the RWGS reaction are based on supported transition metal catalysts such as Cu, Pt and Rh and oxides [1–5]. However, due to their high cost, cheaper catalysts are required. For this reason, transition metal carbides (TMCs) are considered potential catalysts for the RWGS reaction. Some of TMCs have been theoretically and experimentally studied, and their capability of dissociating hydrogen and activating CO2 has been demonstrated [6–11]. Among bulk TMCs, Mo2C is likely the most studied in the RWGS due to its high activity and selectivity [11–17]. These studies include not only how the preparation method of MoxC catalysts affects the catalytic behaviour in the RWGS reaction [14], but also the effect of the addition of other components to Mo2C [15] and the catalytic behaviour of supported Mo2C [16–18]. In previous works we investigated bulk TMCs of group 5 (G5TMCs=VC, NbC, TaC) as catalysts for the RWGS reaction [19,20]. Keeping in mind the advantages of using supported catalysts and the lack of papers reporting the use of supported G5TMCs as RWGS catalysts, here we study the preparation of Al2O3-supported G5TMCs, “G5TMC/Al2O3”, and their use in the RWGS reaction. The use of Al2O3 as support offers several advantages, such as high surface area, thermal stability, and mechanical strength, thereby providing a better performance, durability, and cost-effectiveness compared to other material supports [21]. Moreover, the stability of Al2O3 in the presence of steam makes it a common support for catalysts used in CO2 activation processes [22]. Besides these advantages, the Al2O3 in the interface could play a role in the CO2 activation, as demonstrated for alumina-supported Ni clusters; the CO2 dissociation is favoured on the metal−support interface because the presence of Al3+ Lewis acid centres [22]. Moreover, the presence of alumina could favour the formate decomposition if the RWGS reaction takes place through an associative mechanism, as has been shown for Au/Al2O3 [23]. For Mo2C-based catalysts, the superior performance in the RWGS of those containing non-reducible and acidic supports such as γ-Al2O3 has been reported [24,25]. Additionally, for MoxC/Al2O3 systems, it has recently been demonstrated that surface hydroxyl groups of alumina and the extent of the interface between carbide and alumina play a major role in the RWGS through the formation of bicarbonate species, which can subsequently be transformed into formates and eventually into CO and H2O [18]. In this work, G5TMC were synthesized onto the Al2O3 surface on the base of our previous works, in which the synthesis of bulk G5TMCs catalysts with different characteristics was accomplished [19,20,26]. Several techniques such as N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms, X-ray diffraction (XRD), H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR), Raman spectroscopy, scanning electron microscopy (SEM) with energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) analysis, transmission electron microscopy (TEM), electron diffraction and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) were used for the characterization of fresh- and used-catalysts. The main goal of this investigation is to provide new insights into the use of supported G5TMC catalysts in the selective reduction of CO2 to CO. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of G5TMC/Al2O3 catalysts Catalysts were prepared using a commercial γ-Al2O3 (Alfa Aesar; 226 m2 g−1) as support, VOCl3, VO(isopropoxide)3 , Nb(OC2H5)5 and TaCl5 as G5TM precursors and 4,5-dicyanoimidazole (DI) as carbon source. The method used for the preparation of supported catalysts, which was carried out under Ar to prevent hydrolyzation of metal precursors, was similar to that previously reported for the preparation of bulk G5TMCs [19,20,26], but the preparation was performed in the presence of γ-Al2O3. In short, 4,5-dicyanoimidazole and γ-Al2O3 were added to an alcoholic solution of the metal precursor. Then, the alcohol was evaporated with continuous stirring at room temperature and samples were thermally treated; VC(Cl)/Al2O3 (prepared using VOCl3) and VC(Pr)/Al2O3 (prepared using VO(isopropoxide)3) under Ar flow (100 mL min−1) at 1373 K for 5 h. VC(Pr)H/Al2O3, which was prepared similarly to VC(Pr)/Al2O3, was treated under H2/Ar (5 % v/v) flow instead of Ar. NbC/Al2O3 and TaC/Al2O3 samples were treated under Ar flow (100 mL min−1) at 1473 K for 5 h. After the thermal treatment, catalysts were contacted with air without previous passivation and characterized. See the Supporting Information for more details about the preparation of catalysts. 2.2 Characterization of G5TMC/Al2O3 catalysts N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were recorded at 77 K using a Micromeritics Tristar II 3020 equipment. Multipoint Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) analysis of isotherms was performed for the specific surface area determination. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was carried out using a PANalytical X’Pert PRO MPD Alpha1 diffractometer equipped with a Cu Kα1 radiation source (λ=1.5418 Å). The XRD profiles were collected in the 2θ range of 4–100°, with a step width of 0.017º and counting 50 s at each step. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were acquired using a JEOL J2010F microscope operated at an accelerating voltage up to 200 kV. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was performed on a ZEISS Auriga equipment with an energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) detector under an accelerating voltage up to 20 kV. H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiments were conducted using a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 chemisorption analyser. After a pretreatment at 363 K under He, samples were exposed to H2/Ar (12 % v/v) flow. Afterwards, the temperature was increased up to 1073 K (10 K min−1) and H2 consumption was analysed using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Raman spectra were acquired using a Jobin-Yvon LabRam HR 800, fitted to an optical Olympus BXFM microscope with a 532 nm laser (power limited to 1.5 mW) and a CCD detector. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out using a Perkin Elmer PHI-5500 Multitechnique System (Physical Electronics) with an Al X-ray source (hυ=1486.6 eV and 350 W). All measurements were carried out without any pretreatment in an ultra-high vacuum chamber with a pressure in the 5×10−9-2×10−8 Torr range during data acquisition. The BE values were calculated utilizing the C 1 s BE of adventitious carbon at 284.8 eV, which was previously determined using Au as reference. 2.3 RWGS reaction catalytic tests The RWGS reaction was studied in the 573–873 K range, using a Microactivity-Reference unit (PID Eng&Tech) equipped with a tubular fixed-bed 316-L stainless steel reactor (305 mm long, 9 mm i.d.) and a thermocouple in contact with the catalytic bed. The temperature was increased from room temperature up to 573 K under N2, afterwards the sample was exposed to CO2/H2/N2=1/3/1 flow and the catalytic behaviour was analysed at 573, 623, 673, 723, 773, 823 and 873 K. The catalyst was kept at each temperature 90 min and then the temperature was increased during 10 min; at 873 K, which was the highest temperature, the catalytic behaviour was followed for 4 h. The analysis at a given temperature was carried out by the mean of two analysis after 30 min of stabilization. The experiments were performed with 300 mg of catalyst at 0.1 MPa with a gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 3000 h−1; the volume of the catalytic bed was 1 mL being SiC used as diluent. Catalysts were not pre-treated before the catalytic tests. The products were analysed on-line with a Varian 450-GC equipped with a TCD, a methanizer and two FID detectors. For the most performant catalyst, a stability test (4 days) at 723 K was carried out. The carbon balance between the inlet and outlet gas was ≤ 1 %. CO2 conversion ( X CO 2 ) and selectivity to the i product ( S i ) values were calculated as follows: (2) X CO 2 % = 1 − ( C CO 2 ) outlet ( C CO 2 ) outlet + ∑ ( C i ) outlet · 100 (3) S i % = ( C i ) outlet ∑ ( C i ) outlet · 100 where ( C i ) and C CO 2 are the molar concentration of the i product (CO or CH4) and CO2, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalysts XRD patterns of G5TMC/Al2O3 catalysts mainly showed intense peaks characteristic of G5TMCs: VC (JCPDS 01–073–0476) and/or V8C7 (JCPDS 35–0786) for vanadium-containing catalysts, and NbC (JCPDS 38–1364) and TaC (JCPDS 35–0801) for NbC/Al2O3 and TaC/Al2O3, respectively ( Fig. 1 ). The presence of VC and/or V8C7 cannot be distinguished by XRD because they have similar XRD patterns with main peaks at 2θ=37.7, 43.4, 63.1, 75.6 and 79.7°; V8C7 displays additional peaks with very low intensity ( Fig. 1 ). From now, VCx will refer to the crystalline phases of vanadium carbide nanoparticles onto alumina prepared in this work. XRD pattern of VC(Pr)/Al2O3 (prepared using VO(isopropoxide)3 under Ar flow) showed characteristic peaks of VCx phases wider and less intense than the other VCx-containing catalysts. For bulk catalysts prepared similarly but in the absence of γ-Al2O3, we demonstrated, using Precession Electron Diffraction (PED)-ASTAR characterization, that although the catalysts prepared under Ar flow using VOCl3 or VO(isopropoxide)3 contained both VC and V8C7 phases, VC was the main phase for the bulk catalyst prepared from VOCl3, VC(Cl); meanwhile, V8C7 was the majority phase in the catalyst prepared from VO(isopropoxide)3, VC(Pr) [19]. For NbC and TaC catalysts, the presence of C–vacancies is not favoured according with the C–vacancies energy formation predicted from DFT calculations [20]. During the thermal treatment carried out for the G5TMC/Al2O3 preparation, a partial transformation of the initial γ-Al2O3 (cubic) into rhombohedral and monoclinic Al2O3 took place. Accordingly, when γ-Al2O3 was treated at 1373 K for 5 h under Ar (Al2O3_1373), rhombohedral and monoclinic Al2O3 were formed ( Figure S1 ) [27,28]. Table 1 shows the crystallite sizes of Al2O3-supported carbide phases. VCx in the sample prepared with VO(isopropoxide)3, VC(Pr)/Al2O3, showed a lower crystallite size (7 nm) than that of the sample prepared with VOCl3, VC(Cl)/Al2O3 (57 nm). These results correlate well with our previous studies on bulk VCx catalysts, similarly prepared but in the absence of Al2O3. The mean VCx particle size for VC(Cl) and VC(Pr) was 64.1 and 7 nm respectively; as stated before, VC is the main phase present in VC(Cl) and V8C7 dominates in VC(Pr). Then, it can be reasonably proposed the predominant presence of C-defective V8C7 in VC(Pr)/Al2O3, meanwhile the big particles in VC(Cl)/Al2O3 are mainly related with stoichiometric VC. Using 4,5-dicyanoimidazole as carbon source and appropriate metal precursors, the formation of VCx with controlled low crystallite size can be achieved [19]. The use of VO(isopropoxide)3 would form an appropriate polymeric templating network with the carbon source (DI) preventing the sintering of VCx particles during the thermal treatment, as observed in the preparation of other transition metal carbides [29]. On the other hand, the preparation under flowing H2/Ar, led to a larger crystallite size of VCx in VC(Pr)H/Al2O3 (54 nm) than the preparation under Ar (VC(Pr)/Al2O3, 7 nm). The presence of H2 would change the carburizing system, then influencing the characteristics of the VCx formed, as has been reported for other TMCs such as MoxC [30,31]. An increase in the crystallite size of MoxC has been found when the H2 concentration in the CH4/H2 mixture, used as carburization agent, increased; this effect has been related with the availability of carbidic carbon atoms during the carbide crystallization [31]. Except TaC/Al2O3, all the other catalysts had BET surface areas higher than Al2O3_1373 ( Table 1 ), in general, the polymeric templating network, formed during the preparation of these catalysts, might prevent the loss of surface area during the thermal treatment conducted. SEM-EDX characterization of VCx-containing catalysts indicates a uniform distribution of vanadium carbide onto Al2O3 at the microscale ( Figures S2-S4 ). TEM analysis of VCx/Al2O3 catalysts ( Fig. 2 ) shows in all cases the presence of VCx (V8C7 or VC) nanoparticles, which size depended on the preparation method utilized. According with XRD results, the use of a vanadium alkoxide and Ar treatment (VC(Pr)/Al2O3) led to the smallest VCx mean particle size (7.5 nm) ( Fig. 2 b). On the other hand, a thermal treatment with H2 instead of Ar (VC(Pr)H/Al2O3), or the use of VOCl3 as vanadium precursor (VC(Cl)/Al2O3) resulted in a larger particle size ( Figs. 2 c and 2 a). Moreover, both VC(Cl)/Al2O3 and VC(Pr)H/Al2O3 showed a wider particle size distribution than VC(Pr)/Al2O3. The Raman characterization indicated the presence of residual carbon in the samples; note the D and G bands at 1352 and 1600 cm−1 in Figure S5 . The other Raman bands in the 100–1100 cm−1 zone can be related with the presence of oxy-G5TM surface species [32–34]. VCx/Al2O3 catalysts were more deeply characterized than NbC/Al2O3 and TaC/Al2O3 because the formers were active in the RWGS reaction, whereas NbC/Al2O3 and TaC/Al2O3 were not active. Moreover, the catalytic performance of VCx/Al2O3 catalysts depended on the preparation method, which in turn determined their properties. Fig. 3 shows the H2-TPR profiles of VCx/Al2O3 catalysts, wide peaks with maxima of hydrogen consumption in the range 575–730 K were obtained, which correlate well with those obtained for bulk VC catalysts prepared using similar methods but in the absence of the support [19]. In all cases, a very low amount of H2 was consumed indicating the presence of a low amount of oxy-carbide or oxy-vanadium species [19,26,35], as determined by Raman spectroscopy. Nevertheless, a higher amount of H2 was consumed by VC(Pr)/Al2O3 when compared to VC(Cl)/Al2O3 or VC(Pr)H/Al2O3, in good agreement with the relative intensity of Raman bands in the range 100–1100 cm−1 related with the presence of oxy-vanadium species in the catalysts ( Figure S5 ). The smaller particle size of vanadium carbide in VC(Pr)/Al2O3, compared with VC(Cl)/Al2O3 and VC(Pr)H/Al2O3 could account for this; VC(Pr)/Al2O3, with a higher presence of vanadium carbide on surface, would be more susceptible to oxidation when exposed to air. The surface analysis of vanadium carbide-containing catalysts was carried out by XPS; the V 2p, C 1 s, O 1 s and Al 2p core electron spectra were analysed. The V/Al molar ratios determined by XPS ((V/Al)XPS) and the V content determined by ICP and the corresponding ((V/Al)ICP) are depicted in Table 2. The values indicate a higher VCx dispersion onto the support for VC(Pr)/Al2O3, when compared with the other VCx/Al2O3 catalysts; the lower crystallite size of VCx in VC(Pr)/Al2O3 (7 nm) than in VC(Cl)/Al2O3 (57 nm) and VC(Pr)H/Al2O3 (54 nm) can account for this. Fig. 4 a shows the V 2p spectra; despite the complexity of the spectra, they can be deconvoluted into three V 2p3/2-2p1/2 doublets (intensity ratio V 2p3/2/V 2p1/2=2/1, spin-orbital splitting 7.6 eV). In all cases, the presence of carbide (V 2p3/2= 513.5–513.7 eV) [19,26,36,37] and oxidized species (V 2p3/2= 514.3–514.6 eV and V 2p3/2= 516.3–517.3 eV) [19,26,36–38] can be proposed. For all VCx/Al2O3 catalysts, the C 1 s peak is broad and shows different components besides that of adventitious C (284.8 eV) ( Fig. 4 b); the component at low BE (282.8–283.0 eV) is associated with the presence of VCx [19,26] and that at 285.6–285.9 eV with C-O species, meanwhile CO and C-OO species are responsible of the components at higher BE values [39–41]. For all VCx/Al2O3 catalysts, broad O 1 s bands (maxima ∼532 eV) were obtained ( Figure S6a ) ; Al2O3 gave rise to the main O 1 s component at about 532 eV [42,43]. Oxy-vanadium and oxy-carbide species are related to the components at ∼530–531 eV [19,36,44]; the intensity of these bands is lower for VC(Pr)H/Al2O3 than for the other two samples likely due to the reducing atmosphere used during the preparation. The components at higher BE, 533.2–533.6 eV are associated with the presence of O-C and/or OC [39–41]. It is to recall, that during the RWGS, oxy-carbide species would be continuously removed by H2 forming water within the redox mechanism [11,19]. 3.2 Catalytic performance The RWGS reaction was studied over the different G5TMC/Al2O3 catalysts in the range of 573–873 K, with CO2/H2/N2=1/3/1 at 0.1 MPa and GHSV of 3000 h−1. At 873 K, the catalytic behaviour was followed for 4 h to assess the stability of the catalysts. The main product was CO and only small amounts of CH4 were generated. In all cases, the CO2 conversion values increased with temperature, this is consistent with the endothermic nature of the reaction (Eq. 1). Only VCx-containing catalysts were active; the CO2 conversion values corresponding to NbC/Al2O3 and TaC/Al2O3 were similar to those of the blank test ( Fig. 5 a). A similar trend has recently been determined for the catalytic behaviour of bulk G5TMC in RWGS; the inactivity of NbC and TaC has been related to their low concentration of carbon vacancies [20]. Theoretical predictions have pointed out that the stoichiometric phases of G5TMCs were poorly performant in the CO2 hydrogenation because of the suboptimal H2 activation over them [20]. The better behaviour in the RWGS of VCx/Al2O3 compared to NbC/Al2O3 and TaC/Al2O3 is related with the presence of C vacancies in VCx/Al2O3, and stoichiometric NbC and TaC phases in NbC/Al2O3 and TaC/Al2O3, respectively. This agrees with the higher stability of V8C7 phase with respect VC, meanwhile the stoichiometric cubic NbC and TaC are more stable than the non-stoichiometric phases [20]. The presence of C-vacancies lowers the CO2 dissociation energy barrier, favouring the redox mechanism. This observation has been supported by both experimental and theoretical analyses of CO2 dissociation over group 5 transition metal carbides [20]. For VCx/Al2O3, the CO2 conversion values were in the order: VC(Pr)/Al2O3>VC(Pr)H/Al2O3>VC(Cl)/Al2O3; a similar order is obtained when the CO production per mol of vanadium is considered ( Figure S7 ). Additionally, Figure S7 compares the CO production per mol of vanadium of Al2O3-supported catalysts with that of two bulk VCx catalysts, prepared similarly to VC(Pr)/Al2O3 and VC(Cl)/Al2O3 but in the absence of support, VC(Pr) and VC(Cl), respectively [19]. VC(Pr)/Al2O3 showed about twice CO yield compared to VC(Pr), both having a small mean particle size of VCx (about 7 nm). Meanwhile, VC(Cl)/Al2O3 and VC(Cl), with a bigger mean particle size (60–65 nm) showed similar values of the CO yield per mol of vanadium. As stated in the characterization section, the predominant VCx phases in VC(Pr) and VC(Cl) are V8C7 and VC, respectively [19]. Then, the larger VCx-Al2O3 interface in VC(Pr)/Al2O3 having small VCx particles, likely constituted mainly by V8C7, determines the effect of Al2O3 presence in the CO yield. Throughout the entire temperature range tested, the CO selectivity values achieved with VC(Pr)/Al2O3 were higher than those obtained with VC(Pr)H/Al2O3 or VC(Cl)/Al2O3 ( Fig. 5 b). Nevertheless, the CO selectivity at 773 K or higher temperatures was always higher than 99.5 % for all VCx/Al2O3 catalysts ( Fig. 5 b). Fig. 5 c shows the CO2 conversion at 873 K during the last 4 h of the catalytic test; an initial decrease in the CO2 conversion was observed for VC(Pr)/Al2O3 and VC(Pr)H/Al2O3, being the decrease significantly lower in the last 2 h at 873 K. The apparent activation energies (Ea) for CO production can stress the different behaviour of VCx/Al2O3 catalysts developed in this work. Fig. 5 d presents the corresponding Arrhenius plots, along with those of the bulk catalysts, VC(Pr) and VC(Cl) [19]. For alumina-supported catalysts the order found is Ea VC(Pr)/Al2O3<<Ea VC(Pr)H/Al2O3≈Ea VC(Cl)/Al2O3 ( Fig. 5 d). VC(Pr)/Al2O3, which presents VCx with the lowest crystallite size (7 nm) and the most homogeneous particle size distribution (d̅=7.5 nm), showed the lowest apparent activation energy (41.1±2.9 kJ mol−1); notably, this value is also lower than that obtained over the corresponding unsupported catalyst (VC(Pr), Ea=58.1±4.1 kJ mol−1) similarly prepared but in the absence of support, VC(Pr) was constituted mainly by the C defective V8C7 phase [19]. It is also necessary to highlight that the unsupported catalyst prepared similarly to VC(Cl)/Al2O3 but in the absence of support, VC(Cl), shows an Ea value close to those of VC(Cl)/Al2O3 and VC(Pr)H/Al2O3; in VC(Cl) a crystallite size of about 64 nm and mainly the presence of stoichiometric VC was determined [19]. We attribute the catalytic performance in the RWGS of VC(Pr)/Al2O3 to the presence of small VCx crystallites containing C defective vanadium carbide (V8C7) and the large VCx-Al2O3 interface; the catalytic behaviour of VC(Cl)/Al2O3 and VC(Pr)H/Al2O3 is related with the lower presence of C-vacancies in these samples and the smaller VCx-Al2O3 interface. Table S1 shows the Ea and CO selectivity reported for different alumina-supported and bulk TMCs (MoxC-, VCx- and WC-based) catalysts, in the RWGS reaction under different experimental conditions. All the systems exhibit high CO selectivity, nearing 100 %, thus highlighting the high potential of TMCs as catalysts in the RWGS reaction. Moreover, among them, the here reported VCx/Al2O3, and tailored MoxC-MoC catalysts, exhibited the lowest Ea values [14,19,45–48]. Over stoichiometric and C defective surfaces of vanadium carbide the dissociative mechanism of RWGS has been proposed to occur [19]. In fact, over stoichiometric surfaces, the associative mechanism shows a low energy barrier for -COOH formation but the -COOH decomposition is a step with an energy barrier as high as 1.59 eV [19]. In the case of C defective surfaces, the dissociative mechanism is much favoured with respect the -COOH formation, which is an uphill step [19]. The presence of C vacancies in VCx has been demonstrated to favour the dissociative mechanism for the RWGS. In this context, a higher adsorption energy of CO2 and H2 and a lower energy barrier value for the dissociation of both reactants over a carbon defective surface than over a stoichiometric one, has been theoretically found [19,20]. Therefore, the activation energy for the RWGS over V8C7 is expected to be lower than over VC. Although the results obtained in this work are in line with the major presence of V8C7 in VC(Pr)/Al2O3 and that of VC in VC(Cl)/Al2O3 and VC(Pr)H/Al2O3, it cannot be ruled out that VCx-Al2O3 interface could play a role in the RWGS, as has been demonstrated for alumina supported metallic catalysts and alumina-supported molybdenum carbide [18,22,23]. In fact, this effect could be more important for VC(Pr)/Al2O3, which exhibits the smallest VCx particle size and highest vanadium dispersion on the surface, as determined from XRD, TEM and XPS analysis. The alumina support in VCx/Al2O3, can participate in the CO2 activation as it has been found for alumina-supported Ni clusters and alumina-supported molybdenum carbide [18,22]; alumina could also favour the formate formation from bicarbonate and then its decomposition [18,23]. Characterization of VCx-containing catalysts after the RWGS catalytic test by BET measurements, XRD and XPS pointed out only slights differences when compared with fresh catalysts. During the catalytic test, a diminution of the BET surface area not higher than 10 % took place ( Table 1 ). This small diminution is likely attributed to the formation of H2O during reaction, which can induce hydrothermal degradation of the catalyst, especially at high temperatures, damaging the catalyst’s porous structure [49]. XRD patterns of both used and fresh catalysts were similar ( Figure S8 ) and only a slight increase in the size of vanadium carbide crystallites was determined after reaction ( Table 1 ). In this line, the surface analysis conducted by XPS revealed the presence of carbide species after the catalytic tests (see V 2p and C 1 s spectra in Fig. 4), with only a slight diminution in the V/Al atomic ratio ( Table 2 ). However, a relative increase of the intensity of V 2p and O 1 s signals assigned to oxidized vanadium species was found ( Fig. 4 and Figure S6 ), this is related with an increase in the amount of oxy-carbide and oxy-vanadium species after reaction. For bulk VCx, it has been reported that during the catalytic test, the dissociative CO2 chemisorption onto C-vacancies occurs with VOC formation, then under RWGS conditions VOC species are continuously removed and H2O is formed [19,20]. On the other hand, H2O produced during the RWGS could react with some specific vanadium centres on the surface producing a limited number of oxy-vanadium species during the catalytic test. Therefore, under reaction conditions, carbide, oxy-carbide and oxy-vanadium species would coexist and an increase of oxidized vanadium species could be expected after the catalytic test. NbC/Al2O3 and TaC/Al2O3, which exhibited no activity in the RWGS under the employed reaction conditions, neither showed substantial changes in the BET surface area and XRD results after the catalytic test ( Table 1 and Figure S8 ). A long-term catalytic test (4 days at 723 K) was carried out with the most performant catalyst, VC(Pr)/Al2O3. Fig. 6 displays the CO production and CO selectivity along time. After an initial period (30 h), in which the CO yield slightly decreased, the catalyst showed a quite stable catalytic behaviour with a CO2 conversion of about 11 % and a CO selectivity of near 99.9 %. Moreover, the XRD characterization indicated that the structural characteristics of the catalyst did not change during the long-term catalytic test ( Figure S9 ) showing a VCx crystallite size of 7 nm. The presence of surface carbide species was also determined in this case by XPS ( Figure S10 ); as expected, after the long-term catalytic test, an increase of the amount of surface oxidized species with respect to the fresh catalyst was found ( Figure S10 ). 4 Conclusions In this work, Al2O3-supported G5TMCs catalysts were successfully prepared using γ-Al2O3, different G5TM precursors and 4,5-dicyanoimidazole as C source. Under the experimental conditions used, VCx/Al2O3 catalysts were active in the RWGS reaction, but NbC/Al2O3 and TaC/Al2O3 were inactive. This behaviour is attributed to the presence of non-stoichiometric VCx in VCx/Al2O3, and the solely presence of stoichiometric NbC and TaC phases in NbC/Al2O3 and TaC/Al2O3. The characteristics of the VCx/Al2O3 catalysts depended on the vanadium precursor (VO(isopropoxide)3 or VOCl3) and on the atmosphere used (Ar or H2/Ar (5 %H2)) during catalyst preparation. VC(Pr)/Al2O3, prepared using VO(isopropoxide)3 as vanadium precursor and Ar during the thermal treatment, showed the lowest crystallite size of vanadium carbide, and the highest vanadium dispersion as determined by XPS. VC(Pr)/Al2O3 was also the most performant catalyst in the RWGS reaction. VC(Pr)/Al2O3 exhibited the highest CO production, 8.9 mol CO molV −1 h−1, and the lowest apparent activation energy for CO production, 41.1±2.9 kJ mol−1. This behaviour is related to the major presence of C defective V8C7 in VC(Pr)/Al2O3 and the contribution of the large Al2O3-VCx interface, which would favour the CO2 activation. VC(Pr)/Al2O3 displayed a good stability during the long-term catalytic test carried out at 723 K for 4 days; supported vanadium carbide particles and Al2O3 kept their main characteristics during the catalytic reaction. These results provide new insights for the development of supported VCx catalysts that are effective in the selective reduction of CO2. coredata.dc:description: We show the applicability of a preparation method, previously reported for obtaining tailored bulk VCx catalysts, for alumina-supported G5TMCs. The characteristics of the G5TMCs/Al2O3 catalysts and their behaviour in the selective reduction of CO2 to CO through the RWGS reaction is reported. VCx/Al2O3 catalysts were active, stable and highly selective; meanwhile NbC/Al2O3 and TaC/Al2O3 were not active. VCx/Al2O3 catalysts exhibited selectivity to CO over 99.5 % at temperature above 773 K. The characteristics of alumina-supported vanadium carbide particles depended on the vanadium precursor and on the atmosphere used during the catalyst preparation. XPS characterization of VCx/Al2O3 catalysts revealed the presence of carbide species on surface before and after RWGS reaction. The catalytic behaviour of VCx/Al2O3 is analysed in the light of their characteristics and compared with bulk VCx counterparts. The most performant catalyst, VC(Pr)/Al2O3 , was stable over 4 days at 723 K, with ∼100 % selectivity to CO and CO2 conversion of ∼11 %.

coredata.dc:title: Selective reduction of CO2 to CO over alumina-supported catalysts of group 5 transition metal carbides
